tips: Prune regularly for better blooms.
fun_fact: The oldest fossilized rose was found in Colorado and is estimated to be around 35 million years old!

tips: Deadhead flowers to promote continuous blooming.
fun_fact: In Mexico, marigolds are known as "flowers of the dead" and are used in Día de los Muertos (Day of the Dead) celebrations.

tips: Plant bulbs in autumn for spring blooms.
fun_fact: Daffodils are toxic to rodents, which is why squirrels and rabbits avoid eating them.

tips: Plant bulbs in the fall for spring blooms.
fun_fact: During the 1600s in the Netherlands, tulips were so valuable that they caused "Tulip Mania," where a single bulb could cost as much as a house!

tips: Provide support for tall varieties.
fun_fact: Sunflowers can clean up radiation from soil, as they were used to remove toxins after the Chernobyl disaster.

tips: Prune after flowering to maintain shape.
fun_fact: Ancient Romans used lavender in their baths to keep their skin fresh and fragrant.

tips: Deadhead spent flowers to encourage continuous blooming.
fun_fact: Petunias are known for their ability to repel some garden pests.

tips: Stake tall varieties to prevent them from toppling over.
fun_fact: Dahlias come in nearly every color except true blue.

watering_frequency: Allow soil to dry between waterings
tips: Pinch back stems to encourage bushy growth.
fun_fact: Geraniums are commonly used in perfumes due to their fragrant leaves.

tips: Wear gloves when handling as all parts are toxic.
fun_fact: Oleander is one of the most poisonous commonly grown garden plants.

tips: Provide a trellis for climbing varieties.
fun_fact: Morning Glory flowers open in the morning and close by the afternoon.

tips: Provide high humidity for best growth.
fun_fact: Gardenia flowers are often used in wedding bouquets for their fragrance.

tips: Trim faded blooms to extend the flowering season.
fun_fact: Carnations are often used in floral arrangements due to their long-lasting nature.

tips: Space plants well to ensure good air circulation.
fun_fact: Zinnias were the first flowers grown in space by NASA.

tips: Plant bulbs in succession for continuous blooming.
fun_fact: The name 'Gladiolus' comes from the Latin word for sword.

tips: Deadhead to prolong flowering.
fun_fact: Snapdragons get their name from the resemblance of their blooms to a dragon's mouth.

tips: Fertilize regularly for vibrant blooms.
fun_fact: The Hibiscus sabdariffa variety is used to make a delicious, naturally red herbal tea known as hibiscus tea or "sorrel" in many cultures.

tips: Avoid overwatering to prevent root rot.
fun_fact: Jade plants are often called the "money tree" because they're believed to attract wealth and prosperity.

tips: Thrives in neglect; great for beginners.
fun_fact: NASA found that snake plants can convert CO₂ into oxygen at night, making them one of the best bedroom plants for air purification.

tips: Water sparingly to prevent root rot.
fun_fact: Aloe vera gel contains 99% water but also has over 75 active compounds beneficial for skin and health.

tips: Keep soil moist but not soggy.
fun_fact: Despite its beauty, the peace lily is not a true lily—it belongs to the Araceae family, like philodendrons and anthuriums.

tips: Mist leaves occasionally for humidity.
fun_fact: This palm is often called the "Butterfly Palm" because of its feathery, arching fronds that resemble butterfly wings.

tips: Thrives in water as well as soil.
fun_fact: It can grow in water alone, making it one of the easiest plants to care for with minimal effort.

tips: Wipe leaves occasionally to remove dust.
fun_fact: The white, milky sap of the rubber plant was once used to make natural rubber, hence the name!

tips: Trim branches to encourage bushy growth.
fun_fact: The bright 'flowers' of bougainvillea are actually modified leaves called bracts!

tips: Train vines on a trellis for better growth.

tips: Pinch young plants to encourage bushy growth.
